steps.title: Doddy.
steps.content: Doddy. Here’s one adorable combo of “Daddy” and “Mommy.”

steps.title: Maddy.
steps.content: Maddy. Another version of Daddy + Mommy. This one happens to be a nickname for both Madelyn and Madison. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Mapa.
steps.content: Mapa. Like Mama and Papa, fused into one.

steps.title: Poppy.
steps.content: Poppy. This twist on “pop” also happens to be the name of a beautiful red flower. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Mobby.
steps.content: Mobby. A blend of Mommy + Daddy, with a tiny hint of “Bobbie.”

steps.title: Dama.
steps.content: Dama. Like “mama” and “dada” combined. This one happens to be a formal word for “lady” in Spanish, but it has no such meaning in English! [3] X Research source

steps.title: Noddy.
steps.content: Noddy. Not quite “mommy,” not quite “daddy,” but still 100% “parent.”

steps.title: Zizi.
steps.content: Zizi. Pronounced “Zee-zee,” this one’s a play on Ze/Zir, a gender-neutral pronoun that anyone can use. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Momo.
steps.content: Momo. This one has a touch of “mom” in it, but the extra “o” adds something new.

steps.title: Mimi.
steps.content: Mimi. Another “m” name that pays tribute to many Mimis from LGBT history and lore—from Mimi Márquez to Mimi Imfurst.

steps.title: Nini.
steps.content: Nini. Like “Mimi” and “Nana” combined. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Nommy.
steps.content: Nommy. A nod to “mommy” and “nonbinary,” all in one.

steps.title: Sasa.
steps.content: Sasa. Similar to “Sascha,” a gender-neutral name originating from Germany. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Zaza.
steps.content: Zaza. This one’s just cute. And besides, there’s something about the letter “Z” that’s both endearing and subversive—perfect for those who subvert the gender binary every day.

steps.title: Abba.
steps.content: Abba. Pronounced “Ahh-Bahh” like a sheep’s bah, or “ABBA” like the iconic band.

steps.title: Nony.
steps.content: Nony. Like “Nanny,” but with a twist.

steps.title: Wawa.
steps.content: Wawa. This one’s super easy for babies to pronounce, just like “Dada” or “Mama.” Keep reinforcing it and it’ll become their name for you. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Obi.
steps.content: Obi. Pronounced “Oh-Bee.” Star Wars fans, this one’s for you.

steps.title: Ren.
steps.content: Ren. This name is very easy to pronounce, and is a cute way to shorten "parent"

steps.title: Pamá.
steps.content: Pamá. Pronounced “pah-MAH,” with emphasis on the last syllable. If you’re Latinx, you’ll know that this one is a blend of “mamá” and “papá,” common names for “mom” and “dad” in Spanish and Portuguese. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Mapí.
steps.content: Mapí. A combination of “mamí” and “papí,” the words for “mommy” and “daddy” in many Latinx cultures.

steps.title: Pamita.
steps.content: Pamita. Pronounced “Pah-MEE-tah,” this one is a fusion of “mamita” and “papito,” two more Spanish words for “mommy” and “daddy”

steps.title: Pamito.
steps.content: Pamito. Another twist on “mamita” and “papito.”

steps.title: Maizinho.
steps.content: Maizinho. Pronounced “My-zee-nyoo,” this one is a blend of “Paizinho” and “Mãezinha,” two Portuguese words for “Father” and “Mother.” [9] X Research source

steps.title: Didi.
steps.content: Didi. This one sounds a little like the English word “daddy,” but it’s also a respectful word in Hindi for “older woman.” [10] X Research source

steps.title: Mom and Dad.
steps.content: Mom and Dad. Nonbinary parents can still go by “mom” or “dad” if they want to, just as some non binary people still enjoy wearing dresses or ties. Your name, like your outfits and pronouns, is yours to decide.

steps.title: Papa and Mama.
steps.content: Papa and Mama. If “papa” and “mama” occupy a special place in your heart, you can use either or both—regardless of your assigned gender at birth.

steps.title: Your nickname.
steps.content: Your nickname. If everyone you love calls you “Mikey,” why not your children too? [11] X Research source

steps.title: A special nickname used by your kids.
steps.content: A special nickname used by your kids. If you go by “Ollie” and your infant child mispronounces it as “Orrey,” let it stick. Whatever name they give you, it’ll be yours to keep. No gender required.
